head.supplied: Monomeath ¶ June 13th 76 ¶ My Dear Sir Redmond ¶ ¶ How cruel you are not to tell me where to address my thanks for the excellent photographs you sent me. ¶ ¶ I wrote to you last month at Philadelphi...

div.p: MS 8380, box 66/3 (d), Barry Papers, La Trobe Australian Manuscripts Collection, State Library of Victoria, Melbourne.
How cruel you are not to tell me where to address my thanks for the excellent photographs you sent me.

I wrote to you last month at Philadelphia this time I shall add "Exhibition", but I am very doubtful whether you will get either of these notes. hine illae lachrymae, or rather — no, I forgot I was writing to such a learned and critical Judicial authority, and I will avoid Latin as I have a bad memory for the declensions.

We were very glad that you were elected Chancellor of the University. I don't know whether I am at liberty to tell you but I know that Sir F Murphy was written to to ask whether he would consent to be — I don't know what it is called — nominated I suppose, of course he refused and with other of your friends mustered through to oppose the "Schoolmasters'" attempt to depose the father of the University during his absence. The ungrateful sneaks, I have no patience with them. I hope that is good English.
What a proud position you hold in our hearts as a public benefactor, the most useful and unostentatious public man in Victoria.

Now I turn by way of extreme variation to speak of another man, a man of genius, a lover of science, a sincere friend, but alas, his aims are selfish, his vanity ridiculous, his pretensions absurd. Poor Baron von Mueller. the most tiresome man in the world. He has not known how to secure public respect, but at least he has private simpathy, for a botanist without a garden and laboratory is like a writer without pens & ink, or a carpenter without tools. He was here a few evenings ago and he told me he had asked Mr Turner (I think) to get you made an Oxford Doctor, when you reached home.
The new Bishop is appointed at last. I suppose the Diocese went on just as well without one.
Scarlet fever is the plague of Victoria at present, having succeeded measles. Hitherto our children have escaped.
Now I will waste not more time on the dead letter office, and you must really tell me when and where to greet you with our good wishes and warmest friendship
